The data on the interaction of internal stereoregulating donors (IDs) diethyl 2,4-diisobutyl succinate (DIBS), 2-isopropyl-2-isopentyl-1,3-dimethoxypropane (IPIPDMP) and a mixture of these IDs with the δ-MgCl2 support, and the data on the transformations occurring upon interaction between surface structures of these donors and TiCl4 in model MgCl2/ID/TiCl4 samples were obtained by the chemical analysis and IR spectroscopy. It was found that DIBS interacts with penta- and tetracoordinated Mg ions yielding three types of surface species, while IPIPDMP forms surface species with tetracoordinated Mg ions. In the mixed-donor sample MgCl2/(DIBS+IPIPDMP) donors IPIPDMP and DIBS are anchored to different sites of the MgCl2 surface and do not compete with each other. The interaction of the MgCl2/DIBS sample with TiCl4 leads to the replacing of one third of DIBS anchored to tetracoordinated magnesium ions by TiCl4, while two thirds of TiCl4 are anchored to the vacant sites on MgCl2. In the case of MgCl2/IPIPDMP, TiCl4 is mostly anchored to the vacant sites of MgCl2. Treatment of the mixed-donor MgCl2/(DIBS+IPIPDMP) sample with TiCl4 results in partial removal of DIBS and IPIPDMP and TiCl4 fixation at both vacant and freed surface sites. The data obtained for real highly-active titanium–magnesium catalysts for propylene polymerization containing IPIPDMP, DIBS, and the DIBS+IPIPDMP mixture donors are close to those for the respective MgCl2/ID/TiCl4 model samples. The key difference is that the contents of ID and TiCl4 increase abruptly and the ID/TiCl4 molar ratio changes in real TMCs. Graphical Abstract Keywords Diethyl 2,4-diisobutyl succinate IR spectroscopy 2-isopropyl-2-isopentyl-1,3-dimethoxypropane Propylene polymerization Titanium–magnesium catalysts Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Supported titanium–magnesium Ziegler–Natta catalysts (TMCs) are now the main type of catalytic systems employed to produce isotactic polypropylene (PP). In these catalysts, magnesium dichloride characterized by high surface area, small size of primary crystallites and disordered crystal structure (“activated” δ-MgCl2) is used as a support. Titanium tetrachloride (active component) and electron-donating organic compounds with a specified structure (internal donors, IDs) are anchored to this support. Internal donors within TMC ensure the desired high stereospecificity of these catalysts, which is required to produce isotactic polypropylene [1–8]. It is also noteworthy that the composition of internal donors affects the molecular weight and molecular weight distribution (MWD) of the resulting polypropylene. Dialkyl phthalates, dialkyl succinates and dialkyl 1,3-dimethoxypropanes are the most typical internal donors used in TMCs. PP with a narrow MWD (polydispersity index Mw/Mn = 3–4) is produced over TMCs containing dialkyl 1,3-dimethoxypropanes; TMCs containing dialkyl phthalates are used to produce PP with a broader MWD (Mw/Mn = 4–5); and PP with the broadest MWD (Mw/Mn = 5–7) is produced over catalysts containing dialkyl succinates [3,7]. The probable reason for various MWD is related to different patterns in the heterogeneity of the active sites in these catalysts in chain termination reactions. Plenty of data on the composition and structure of the surface species of the internal donors on the MgCl2 support surface within titanium–magnesium catalysts obtained using different physical methods and quantum chemical calculations are available in the literature [9–25]. However, these data still cannot elucidate the association between the composition and the structure of the surface species of internal donors within titanium–magnesium catalysts and the molecular weight distribution of polypropylene produced over these catalysts. The most significant differences in the composition of the surface species of internal donors are observed between dialkyl 1,3-dimethoxypropanes and internal donors containing carboxyl functional groups (dialkyl phthalates and dialkyl succinates). Dialkyl 1,3-dimethoxypropanes preferentially interact with tetracoordinated magnesium ions on the δ-MgCl2 surface yielding surface chelate complexes [9–12,17,20]. Meanwhile, dialkyl phthalates and dialkyl succinates preferentially interact with pentacoordinated magnesium ions on the δ-MgCl2 surface forming bridged complexes, but can also interact with tetracoordinated magnesium ions on the δ-MgCl2 surface [9,11–15,20]. A number of studies addressing mixed-donor titanium–magnesium catalysts that contain dialkyl 1,3-dimethoxypropane and dialkyl succinate as internal donors have been published over the past years [26,27]. These catalysts were prepared for manufacturing polypropylene with the polydispersity index corresponding to that of polypropylene produced over TMCs containing dialkyl phthalates as an internal donor. In the present study, we employed the chemical analysis and IR spectroscopy to investigate the interaction between “activated” δ-MgCl2 and electron donors, diethyl 2,4-diisobutyl succinate (DIBS) and 2-isopropyl-2-isopentyl-1,3-dimethoxypropane (IPIPDMP), as well as a mixture of these donors, and transformations occurring upon interaction between δ-MgCl2/ID samples and tetrachloride titanium. The findings for the δ-MgCl2/ID/TiCl4 model samples were compared to the data obtained for real highly-active titanium–magnesium catalysts containing IPIPDMP and DIBS, as well as a mixture of these internal donors. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Stereoregulating electron-donating compounds ( Fig. 1), 2-isopropyl-2-isopentyl-1,3-dimethoxypropane (IPIPDMP) and diethyl 2,3-diisobutyl succinate (DIBS), were synthesized according to the procedure described in refs. [28,29]. The synthesized DIBS sample contained rac and meso stereoisomers of DIBS at rac/meso = 0.9. IPIPDMP, DIBS, chlorobenzene, and hexane were dried over molecular sieves. 2.2 Preparation of supports and catalysis Magnesium chloride was prepared for the experiments via interaction between magnesium metal and butyl chloride according to the procedure described in ref. [30]. The resulting MgCl2 sample (specific surface area SBET = 80 m2/g) contained approximately 10 wt% organic polymeric products. The MgCl2/IPIPDMP, MgCl2/DIBS, and MgCl2/(DIBS+IPIPDMP) samples were prepared by adding a calculated amount of IPIPDMP, DIBS or the IPIPDMP+DIBS donors mixture to magnesium dichloride suspension in PhCl (25 mL of PhCl per 1 g MgCl2) at 115 °C. The mixture was stirred at the specified temperature for 60 min, washed once with chlorobenzene at the preparation temperature, and washed thrice with heptane at room temperature. To produce the model samples MgCl2/IPIPDMP/TiCl4, MgCl2/DIBS/TiCl4, and MgCl2/(DIBS+IPIPDMP)/TiCl4, chlorobenzene (25 mL of PhCl per 1 g MgCl2), MgCl2/ID and TiCl4 were added into the reactor at a Ti/Mg molar ratio = 100; the mixture was left exposed to 115 °C under stirring, and washed with heptane thrice at room temperature. Titanium–magnesium catalysts TMC-1, TMC-2, and TMC-3 were prepared according to the procedure described in ref. [31]. Magnesium-containing pre-support with the composition 2 Mg(OEt)2 · MgCl2, was prepared at the first stage via interaction between organomagnesium compound Mg3Ph4Cl2 and Si(OEt)4 in dibutyl ester and chlorobenzene. The second stage involved an interaction between the resulting pre-support and excess titanium tetrachloride (Ti/Mg molar ratio = 30) in the presence of internal donors IPIPDMP, DIBS, or a mixture of these compounds (ID/Mg molar ratio = 0.15) at 115 °C. Next, the catalyst samples were washed thrice with heptane at room temperature. The average particle size in the resulting catalysts was ∼ 25 µm. The data on the chemical composition of the catalysts will be discussed in the Section 3. 2.3 Chemical analysis The titanium content was determined by AES-ICP method applied to the catalyst solution in 5 % aqueous solution of H2SO4 used a Perkin-Elmer Optima 4300 DV spectrometer. The contents of the internal donors IPIPDMP and DIBS were measured by gas chromatography of the catalyst solution in acetonitrile on a Khromos GKh-1000 chromatography system equipped with an SGE BP1 GC column (0.25 µm × 0.32 µm × 25 m) and a flame ionization detector (FID). Helium was used as a carrier gas; dimethyl phthalate was used as an internal standard. 2.4 FTIR measurements Samples for the IR spectroscopy analysis were vacuum-dried at a residual pressure of 1.5 × 10−2 torr. After drying, the samples (0.02–0.04 g) were placed into a measurement cell under inert atmosphere. The IR spectra were recorded using a Shimadzu FTIR-8400S spectrometer in the wavelength range of 400–6000 cm–1. The spectral resolution was 4 cm–1. 2.5 Propylene polymerization and analysis of polymers Propylene polymerization was conducted in a 1 L steel autoclave in 300 mL of heptane at 70 °C, propylene pressure of 6 atm, in the presence of 2 vol% hydrogen in the gas phase of the reactor, AlEt3 (4 mmol/L), and an additional stereoregulating electron-donating compound (an external donor), cyclohexylmethyldimethoxysilane (CHMDMS), at an Al/CHMDMS molar ratio = 20. The polymerization time was 60 min. The isotacticity index of polypropylene (II, wt%) was calculated as II = 100 – XS, where XS is the relative amount of the xylene-soluble fraction determined according to the procedure described in ref. [32]. The polydispersity of polypropylene (the width of the molecular weight distribution of polypropylene calculated as the ratio between the weight average molecular weight Mw and the number average molecular weight Mn) was determined by high-temperature gel permeation chromatography in 1,2,4-trichlorobenzene at 160 °C on a PL 220 chromatography system. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Study of the DIBS and IPIPDMP interaction with MgCl2 and the model samples with compositions MgCl2/ID and MgCl2/ID/TiCl4 Titanium–magnesium catalysts for propylene polymerization containing stereoregulating electron-donating compounds (internal donors, IDs) are usually synthesized via interaction between magnesium-containing compounds with different composition (pre-supports) and titanium tetrachloride in the presence of internal donors. In this case, the internal donor, together with TiCl4, participates in the formation of highly-active titanium–magnesium catalysts containing “activated” δ-MgCl2 (characterized by a small size of primary crystallites (2–15 nm) and a disordered crystal structure) as a support [6–13,25]. In order to assess the pattern of interaction between an ID and δ-MgCl2, as well as the state of the ID anchored to the δ-MgCl2 support and the potential effect of TiCl4 on the state of ID within TMC more accurately, we preliminarily investigated the model systems produced via interaction between ID and δ-MgCl2 prepared in the absence of an ID (MgCl2/ID), as well as the systems prepared by treating these MgCl2/ID model samples with titanium tetrachloride (MgCl2/ID/TiCl4). 3.1.1 Interaction of DIBS and IPIPDMP with MgCl2 DIBS consisting of two stereoisomers, with the rac/meso ratio = 0.9, was used in this study. Previously, we demonstrated [33] that upon interaction of this DIBS sample with MgCl2, the rac stereoisomer of DIBS is preferentially anchored to the magnesium dichloride surface, and the ratio between the rac/meso isomers of DIBS in the MgCl2/DIBS sample is 2.2–2.9. Table 1 (exps. 1 and 2) lists the data on the DIBS content in the MgCl2/DIBS samples obtained at a DIBS/MgCl2 molar ratios 0.05 and 0.10. One can see that the amount of fixed DIBS slightly rises with increasing DIBS/MgCl2 molar ratio when these samples are prepared, and reaches the value of 210 μmol/g MgCl2. Potapov et al. [14] obtained the data on the interaction (at 115 °C and molar ratio DBP/Mg = 0.1) between di-n-butyl phthalate (DBP) and δ-MgCl2 prepared using the same procedure as the one employed in this study. They reported that the amount of di-n-butyl phthalate anchored to MgCl2 was 250 μmol/g. One can see that this value is close to the amount of DIBS (210 μmol/g) anchored to the same support (Table 1, exp. 2). Fig. 2 shows the IR spectra of the DIBS solution and the MgCl2/DIBS sample. A broad absorption band at 1550–1750 cm–1 appears in the spectrum of the MgCl2/DIBS sample. Three absorption bands peaking at 1615, 1670, and 1700 cm–1 can be detected by deconvoluting this band into individual components. The presence of these absorption bands is related to the emergence of three groups of surface species formed upon interaction between DIBS and acidic surface sites of magnesium dichloride. A similar shape of the IR spectrum, with a broad band in the region of 1600–1750 cm–1, was also observed in ref. [14] for the MgCl2/DBP sample prepared using the procedure close to that used for the MgCl2/DIBS sample presented in Table 1 (exp. 2) and Fig. 2. Table 1 (exp. 3) lists the data on the IPIPDMP content in the MgCl2/IPIPDMP sample prepared at an molar ratio IPIPDMP/MgCl2 = 0.10. One can see that the IPIPDMP content in this sample (431 μmol/g) is substantially higher than the DIBS content in the MgCl2/DIBS sample (210 μmol/g MgCl2, exp. 2, Table 1). Fig. 3 shows the IR spectrum of the MgCl2/IPIPDMP sample and a solution of the initial IPIPDMP sample in CCl4. One can see that as a result of IPIPDMP anchoring to magnesium dichloride, a new broad absorption band appears in the IR spectrum in the region of 1000–1080 cm–1, characterizing the νs (C−O−C) and νas (C−O−C) of IPIPDMP anchored to the acidic surface sites of magnesium chloride. This band contains two peaks at 1023 and 1060 cm–1. According to the quantum chemical calculations made in ref. [9], 1,3-diethers are preferentially anchored to the magnesium chloride surface as chelate complexes on tetracoordinated magnesium ions that are present on the (110) face. Meanwhile, only 1,3-diethers having C2 symmetry (TG+G+T conformer) and C3 symmetry (TG+G-T conformer) can be adsorbed. In the region of 1000–1100 cm−1 in the IR spectrum, each conformer must have two absorption bands corresponding to νas of the (C−O−C) groups [9]. It is fair to assume based on these data that the absorption bands at 1023 and 1060 cm–1 belong to IPIPDMP adsorbed on tetracoordinated magnesium ions with C2 symmetry (TG+G+T conformer) and C3 symmetry (TG+G-T conformer). We also studied mixed-donor MgCl2/ID samples containing both stereoregulating donors (DIBS and IPIPDMP). The mixed-donor MgCl2/ID samples were prepared by co-adsorption of these species onto magnesium chloride. Two mixed-donor samples with the composition MgCl2/(DIBS+IPIPDMP) were obtained using the same molar ratio DIBS/IPIPDMP = 1 but different ID/MgCl2 molar ratios (0.05 and 0.10) during the preparation of the samples. Table 1 (exps. 4 and 5) lists the data on the contents of DIBS and IPIPDMP in the mixed-donor samples. One can see that the DIBS content in mixed-donor samples is close to that obtained for MgCl2/DIBS samples (Table 1, exps. 1 and 2). Meanwhile, the IPIPDMP content in the mixed-donor samples (exps. 4–5, 185–245 μmol/g) is noticeably lower compared to the content of this ID in the MgCl2/IPIPDMP sample (Table 1, exp. 3, 431 μmol/g). The total content of ID in the mixed-donor sample (exp. 5, 521 μmol/g) is higher than the IPIPDMP content in the MgCl2/IPIPDMP sample (exp. 3, 431 μmol/g). The data listed in Table 1 (exp. 4) indicate that upon co-adsorption of DIBS and IPIPDMP onto MgCl2 at the lower molar ratio ID/MgCl2 = 0.05, these stereoregulating donors interact with different sites on the MgCl2 surface and do not compete with each other. At the higher molar ratio ID/MgCl2 = 0.10 (exp. 5, Table 1), DIBS is probably additionally anchored to some surface sites on MgCl2 that can potentially also anchor IPIPDMP. Fig. 4 shows the IR spectra of the mixed-donor MgCl2/(DIBS+IPIPDMP) sample. According to the data listed in Table 1 (exp. 4), the DIBS content in this sample is close to that in the MgCl2/DIBS sample (exp. 1, Table 1). Therefore, in the region of 1570–1750 cm–1, the broadened IR spectra of these samples contain three identical components peaking at 1615, 1670, and 1700 cm–1 (Figs. 2 and 4). The positions of these peaks and the intensity ratio of these components for the MgCl2/DIBS and MgCl2/(DIBS+IPIPDMP) samples are identical (Figs. 2 and 4). The IR spectrum of the mixed-donor MgCl2/(DIBS+IPIPDMP) sample in the region of 980–1080 cm–1 contains two peaks at 1023 and 1060 cm–1 that are identical to the IR spectrum of the MgCl2/IPIPDMP sample (compare Figs. 3 and 4). These data demonstrate that IPIPDMP and DIBS in the mixed-donor sample produced at the molar ratio IPIPDMP/MgCl2 = 0.05 and molar ratio DIBS/MgCl2 = 0.05 are adsorbed onto different sites of MgCl2 and do not compete with each other. 3.1.2 Study of the interaction between TiCl4 and MgCl2/ID model samples Table 2 lists the data on the compositions of the MgCl2/ID/TiCl4 samples obtained by treating the MgCl2/ID model samples with titanium tetrachloride at 115 °C and molar ratio TiCl4/MgCl2 = 100. One can see that more than 50 % of DIBS is removed from the MgCl2/DIBS sample after its treatment with titanium tetrachloride (exps. 1 and 2, Table 2). Meanwhile, the content of titanium tetrachloride anchored to MgCl2 (300 μmol/g) is significantly higher than the DIBS content in the MgCl2/DIBS/TiCl4 sample (98 μmol/g). Our earlier study revealed that the rac and meso stereoisomers of DIBS exist in the MgCl2/DIBS sample at a 2.2: 1 ratio. The interaction between this sample and TiCl4 results in preferential removal of the meso isomer of DIBS and increases the rac/meso ratio to 6: 1 [33]. Hence, the DIBS content is reduced during the interaction between the MgCl2/DIBS sample and titanium tetrachloride preferentially due to removal of the meso stereoisomer of DIBS that has weaker binding to MgCl2. TiCl4 is potentially anchored to these newly vacant sites on the MgCl2 surface. Moreover, a significant share of TiCl4 (ca. 60 %) is anchored to vacant surface sites that were present in the initial MgCl2/DIBS sample before its interaction with TiCl4. The treatment of the MgCl2/IPIPDMP sample with titanium tetrachloride slightly reduces the IPIPDMP content (exps. 3 and 4, Table 2). The content of MgCl2-anchored TiCl4 (206 μmol/g) is significantly lower than the IPIPDMP content in this sample (370 μmol/g). In this case, TiCl4 is preferentially anchored to vacant surface sites that were present in the initial MgCl2/IPIPDMP sample before its interaction with TiCl4. The treatment of the mixed-donor MgCl2/(DIBS+IPIPDMP) sample with titanium tetrachloride (exps. 5 and 6, Table 2) significantly reduces the DIBS and IPIPDMP contents in this sample and results in TiCl4 anchoring to MgCl2 at a molar ratio TiCl4/(DIBS+IPIPDMP) = 0.64. The amount of anchored TiCl4 (200 μmol/g) corresponds to the amount of DIBS+IPIPDMP removed from the MgCl2/(DIBS+IPIPDMP) sample upon its interaction with TiCl4 (209 μmol/g). TiCl4 is possibly anchored to MgCl2 by being adsorbed onto the newly vacant sites in the catalyst support. The IR spectra of the solutions of TiCl4 · DIBS and TiCl4 · IPIPDMP complexes in carbon tetrachloride are shown in Fig. 5. These data are needed to more accurately assess the IR spectroscopy data presented in Figs. 6 and 7 for the MgCl2 ID/TiCl4 samples prepared by treating MgCl2/ID samples with titanium tetrachloride. As DIBS interacts with TiCl4, the absorption band at 1733 cm–1 corresponding to ν (CO) of the carboxyl group in DIBS disappears from the IR spectrum, while the band at 1670 cm–1 corresponding to ν (CO) of the carboxyl group in DIBS in the formed DIBS · TiCl4 complex appears (Fig. 5A). The position of this absorption band coincides with the position of one of the bands (1670 cm–1) obtained at deconvolution of a broad band in the IR spectrum in the region of 1550–1720 cm–1 for the sample containing MgCl2-anchored DIBS (Fig. 2). It is fair to assume that chelate complexes comprising two carbonyl groups of DIBS and tetracoordinated Ti (IV) ions (for the DIBS · TiCl4 complex) or tetracoordinated Mg (II) ions on the MgCl2 surface (for the MgCl2/DIBS sample) are formed in both cases. Upon interaction between IPIPDMP and TiCl4, the absorption band at 1112 cm–1 corresponding to the ν (C−O−C) in IPIPDMP disappears, while two new absorption bands at 1005 and 1030 cm–1 appear in the IR spectrum (Fig. 4B). Previously, Brambilla et al. [9] studied the interaction between a 1,3-diether (9,9`-bis(methoxymethyl)fluorine, BMMF) and TiCl4 by IR spectroscopy and quantum chemical DFT calculations. They demonstrated that only the TG+G+T (C2 symmetry) and TG+G-T (C3 symmetry) conformers can participate in the formation of this complex. Two well-defined components in the C−O−C antisymmetric stretching region were observed for each conformer upon the formation of the BMMF · TiCl4 chelate complex comprising two C−O−C groups in the region of 1000–1050 cm–1. Findings obtained in ref. [9] suggest that absorption bands at 1005 cm–1 and 1030 cm–1 correspond to νas (C−O−C) in the complexes formed upon interaction between IPIPDMP and TiCl4. Note that the positions of these bands are close to those of the two peaks at 1023 and 1060 cm–1, which are observed in the broad absorption band of surface species formed via interaction between IPIPDMP and MgCl2 (Fig. 3). We believe that in the cases of the IPIPDMP · TiCl4 complex and IPIPDMP surface species on MgCl2, identical chelate complexes of IPIPDMP comprising two ether groups of IPIPDMP and tetracoordinated Ti (IV) ions (for the IPIPDMP · TiCl4 complex) or complexes of IPIPDMP with tetracoordinated Mg (II) ions on the MgCl2 surface (for the IPIPDMP/MgCl2 samples) are formed. Figs. 6 and 7 show the IR spectra of the MgCl2/ID/TiCl4 samples compared to the IR spectra of the initial MgCl2/ID samples before their interaction with TiCl4. The shape of the IR spectrum of the MgCl2/DIBS/TiCl4 sample (Fig. 6, spectrum 2) is close to that of the IR spectrum of the initial MgCl2/DIBS sample (Fig. 6, spectrum 1). Three identical absorption bands at 1615, 1670, and 1700 cm–1 can be detected in these spectra. Only the intensity of the absorption band at 1670 cm–1 was reduced compared to the band at 1700 cm–1 in the initial MgCl2/DIBS/TiCl4 sample (spectrum 1): the intensity ratio I1670/I1700 decreases from 1.0 (spectrum 1) to 0.7 (spectrum 2). These findings indicate that DIBS anchored to tetracoordinated magnesium ions was preferentially removed during treatment of the MgCl2/DIBS sample with titanium chloride. The IR spectrum of the MgCl2/IPIPDMP/TiCl4 sample is close to that of the initial MgCl2/IPIPDMP sample in terms of its shape and position of absorption bands (Fig. 7). As mentioned above, the chemical analysis data of the MgCl2/IPIPDMP and MgCl2/IPIPDMP/TiCl4 samples indicated that the contents of the internal donor are similar in these samples (Table 2, exps. 3 and 4). In this case, TiCl4 is possibly anchored to the vacant sites on the MgCl2 surface, which are present in the MgCl2/IPIPDMP sample. 3.2 IR spectroscopic study of the composition of supported titanium–magnesium catalysts as well as DIBS and IPIPDMP surface species in these catalysts Table 3 lists the data on propylene polymerization and compositions of the catalysts containing donors IPIPDMP (TMC-1), DIBS (TMC-2), and a mixture of these donors (TMC-3). The catalysts were characterized by high activity and stereospecificity in propylene polymerization. TMC-1 containing donor IPIPDMP produces polypropylene with a narrow MWD (Mw/Mn = 3.6–3.8, exps. 1 and 2 in Table 3). Meanwhile, TMC-2, which contains DIBS donor, produces polypropylene with the broadest MWD (Mw/Mn = 5.2, exp. 3 in Table 3). The mixed-donor catalyst TMC-3 (exp. 4, Table 3) containing both DIBS and IPIPDMP donor produces PP with the intermediate polydispersity index (Mw/Mn = 4.5) and intermediate molecular weight of polypropylene. The comparative data on the contents of the internal donors and titanium in the catalysts TMC-1, TMC-2, and TMC-3 and in the MgCl2/ID/TiCl4 model samples are summarized in Table 4. One can see that the content of the internal donors and titanium in the catalysts TMC-1 and TMC-2 is two to five times higher than the content of these components in the MgCl2/ID/TiCl4 model systems prepared with the δ-MgCl2 support formed in the absence of internal donors. It is possibly related to the higher specific surface area, smaller size of primary crystallites, and higher degree of the crystal structure disorder of magnesium dichloride in titanium–magnesium catalysts compared to those of the MgCl2/ID/TiCl4 model systems (the data for these systems are listed in Tables 1 and 2). TMC-1 contains 2.1 times more IPIPDMP donor than the amount of DIBS donor in the catalyst TMC-2 (compare exps. 2 and 4 in Table 4). A similar situation is also observed for the MgCl2/ID/TiCl4 model systems where the IPIPDMP content is 3.8 times higher than that of DIBS (compare exps. 1 and 3 in Table 4). In the catalysts TMC-1, TMC-2, and TMC-3 characterized by high activity and stereospecificity, the ID/Ti molar ratios are close and within the range from 0.87 to 1.2 (Table 4, exps. 2, 4, and 6). TMC-1 containing IPIPDMP as an internal donor is characterized by higher activity and stereospecificity compared to TMC-2 containing DIBS as an internal donor (Table 3). These findings are consistent with the data on the higher contents of titanium and internal donor in TMC-1 compared to TMC-2 (Table 4, exps. 2 and 4). Fig. 8 shows the IR spectra of the catalysts TMC-1, TMC-2, and TMC-3 within the region of stretching vibrations of C−O−C ether groups characterizing the IPIPDMP surface species in the catalysts TMC-1 and TMC-3 (Fig. 8A) and in the region of stretching vibrations of carbonyl groups CO, which characterize DIBS surface species in the catalysts TMC-2 and TMC-3 (Fig. 8B). The IR spectrum of TMC-1 (Fig. 8A, spectrum 1) is identical to the spectrum of the MgCl2/IPIPDMP/TiCl4 model sample shown in Fig. 7 (spectrum 2). Both spectra contain a broad absorption band at 1000–1100 cm–1 with two peaks at 1023 and 1060 cm–1. As mentioned above, this spectrum corresponds to the chelate complex IPIPDMP, which is formed via interaction between C−O−C ether groups in IPIPDMP and tetracoordinated magnesium ions on the δ-MgCl2 surface. The IR spectrum of TMC-2 (Fig. 8B, spectrum 2) is close to that of the MgCl2/DIBS/TiCl4 model sample shown in Fig. 6. Both spectra contain a broad absorption band at 1600–1702 cm–1, peaking at 1615, 1670, and 1700 cm–1. As mentioned above, these absorption bands could have emerged due to the formation of three types of surface DIBS species having different structures through interaction between the carbonyl groups of DIBS and tetracoordinated magnesium ions on the δ-MgCl2 surface (absorption bands at 1615 and 1670 cm–1) and pentacoordinated magnesium ions (absorption band at 1700 cm–1). Fig. 8 shows the spectra of the catalyst TMC-3 containing IPIPDMP and DIBS at a 1: 3 molar ratio (Table 4, exp. 6): spectrum 3a in the region of 950–1100 cm–1 and spectrum 3b in the region of 1550–1750 cm–1. One can see that this catalyst contains IPIPDMP surface species (absorption bands at 1023 and 1060 cm–1) anchored to tetracoordinated Mg ions on the δ-MgCl2 support, similar to those formed in the MgCl2/IPIPDMP/TiCl4 sample (Fig. 7, curve 2) and TMC-1 (Fig. 8A, spectrum 1), as well as DIBS surface species (absorption bands at 1615, 1670 and 1700 cm−1 (Fig. 7B, spectrum 3b), similar to those formed in the MgCl2/DIBS/TiCl4 sample (Fig. 6, curve 2) and TMC-2 (Fig. 8B, spectrum 2). The key differences between the mixed-donor catalyst TMC-3 and the MgCl2/(IPIPDMP+DIBS)/TiCl4 sample are the higher contents of TiCl4 and DIBS and the optimal ID/TiCl4 ratio equal to 1.0 (exps. 5 and 6, Table 4). The significant differences in the compositions of the catalysts TMC-1, TMC-2, and TMC-3 compared to that of the MgCl2/ID/TiCl4 model samples are apparently related to differences in the conditions used when preparing the model samples and the catalysts. The model samples were prepared by sequential interaction of the internal donor (first) and TiCl4 (second) with the δ-MgCl2 support, which was preliminarily produced in the absence of an internal donor and TiCl4. Meanwhile, the real catalysts were prepared via interaction between a magnesium-containing pre-support with composition 2 Mg(OR)2 · MgCl2 and titanium tetrachloride in the presence of an internal donor. The presence of an internal donor during formation of the δ-MgCl2 support and the final catalyst allows one to produce supports and catalysts characterized by high surface area, small crystallite size, and increased disorder of the crystal structure of δ-MgCl2. It was shown in the previous studies [25,34] that co-presence of an internal donor and TiCl4 during the formation of a titanium–magnesium catalyst yields the δ-MgCl2 support characterized by an optimal composition of ID and TiCl4 surface species, ensuring high catalyst activity and isotacticity of the produced polypropylene. 4 Conclusions The data on the interactions of donors DIBS, IPIPDMP and a mixture of these donors with the δ-MgCl2 support and data on the transformations occurring upon the following treatment by titanium tetrachloride (MgCl2/ID/TiCl4 samples) were obtained by the chemical analysis and IR spectroscopy. It was found that in the MgCl2/DIBS sample DIBS interacts with penta- and tetracoordinated magnesium ions on the δ-MgCl2 surface yielding three types of surface species. Treatment of that sample with TiCl4 noticeably reduces the DIBS content and results in the anchoring of 300 μmol/g TiCl4. Approximately one third of this TiCl4 replaces the DIBS surface species anchored to tetracoordinated magnesium ions, while two thirds of TiCl4 are anchored to vacant sites on the MgCl2 surface that were present in the initial MgCl2/DIBS sample. It was shown that IPIPDMP forms surface species anchoring to tetracoordinated magnesium ions on the surface of δ-MgCl2 support. Treatment of the MgCl2/IPIPDMP sample with TiCl4 leads to the anchoring of TiCl4 on the vacant sites of the MgCl2 surface that were present in the initial MgCl2/IPIPDMP sample. In the mixed-donor MgCl2/(DIBS+IPIPDMP) sample the IPIPDMP and DIBS donors are anchored to different sites of the MgCl2 surface and do not compete with each other. Treatment of the mixed-donor MgCl2/(DIBS+IPIPDMP) sample with TiCl4 results in the anchoring of TiCl4 to the surface sites of δ-MgCl2, which became vacant after some ID had been removed from the initial MgCl2/(DIBS+IPIPDMP) sample. The data obtained for real highly active catalysts for propylene polymerization containing IPIPDMP (TMC-1), DIBS (TMC-2), and a DIBS/IPIPDMP mixture (TMC-3) as internal donors are close to those of the respective model systems MgCl2/IPIPDMP/TiCl4, MgCl2/DIBS/TiCl4, and MgCl2/(DIBS+IPIPDMP)/TiCl4. The key difference between the catalysts and the respective MgCl2/ID/TiCl4 model samples is that the contents of ID and TiCl4 are abruptly increased and the ID/Ti ratio in the catalysts reaches the optimal value of 0.9–1.2, unlike the model samples for which this value is 1.8 (for the MgCl2/IPIPDMP/TiCl4 sample), 0.33 (for the MgCl2/DIBS/TiCl4 sample), and 1.6 (for the MgCl2/(DIBS+IPIPDMP)/TiCl4 sample). The revealed differences are related to the fact that the δ-MgCl2 support in real TMCs is formed in the presence of an internal donor, which allows one to produce a catalyst characterized by high specific surface area, small size of primary microcrystallites, and disordered crystal structure. It leads to the high content of internal donors and TiCl4, as well as the optimal ID/TiCl4. coredata.dc:description: The data on the interaction of internal stereoregulating donors (IDs) diethyl 2,4-diisobutyl succinate (DIBS), 2-isopropyl-2-isopentyl-1,3-dimethoxypropane (IPIPDMP) and a mixture of these IDs with the δ-MgCl2 support, and the data on the transformations occurring upon interaction between surface structures of these donors and TiCl4 in model MgCl2/ID/TiCl4 samples were obtained by the chemical analysis and IR spectroscopy. It was found that DIBS interacts with penta- and tetracoordinated Mg ions yielding three types of surface species, while IPIPDMP forms surface species with tetracoordinated Mg ions. In the mixed-donor sample MgCl2/(DIBS+IPIPDMP) donors IPIPDMP and DIBS are anchored to different sites of the MgCl2 surface and do not compete with each other. The interaction of the MgCl2/DIBS sample with TiCl4 leads to the replacing of one third of DIBS anchored to tetracoordinated magnesium ions by TiCl4, while two thirds of TiCl4 are anchored to the vacant sites on MgCl2. In the case of MgCl2/IPIPDMP, TiCl4 is mostly anchored to the vacant sites of MgCl2. Treatment of the mixed-donor MgCl2/(DIBS+IPIPDMP) sample with TiCl4 results in partial removal of DIBS and IPIPDMP and TiCl4 fixation at both vacant and freed surface sites. The data obtained for real highly-active titanium–magnesium catalysts for propylene polymerization containing IPIPDMP, DIBS, and the DIBS+IPIPDMP mixture donors are close to those for the respective MgCl2/ID/TiCl4 model samples. The key difference is that the contents of ID and TiCl4 increase abruptly and the ID/TiCl4 molar ratio changes in real TMCs.
